description:
Today young men return to the Spanish countryside as austerity bites in the big cities. Droughts, the threat in the American state of Nebraska - there farmers say they're losing the battle against the elements. We walk through the poppy fields of Gallipoli, 97 years after a battle, in which 130,000 lives were lost, and the locals are on holiday. The streets are quiet, the air is pure. August in Paris, it's like a month of Sundays.

There are clouds gathering over the Spanish government this weekend. It's reported to be close to seeking a multi-billion-euro bailout from the EU and the European Central Bank. That'll mean further deep austerity measures, which in turn could lead to protests on the streets, even a general strike. Trades Union representatives met King Juan Carlos earlier this week. They told him they were opposed to the new rescue package because it would increase the hardship for Spaniards already suffering from two years of harsh austerity measures.

Chris Stewart who lives and farms in the south of the country says the economic crisis is having some unexpected consequences in rural communities.

"No hay mal que por bien no venga" is what the Spanish say when they want to point out that every cloud has a silver lining. 20 years ago, Peck Sanchez and I used to talk about a utopia, in which all the abandoned land in the Alpujarra would be beautifully farmed. We dreamed that young people, tired of the blandishments of urban life, would return to the land, burning with agricultural idealism and would recreate the garden of Eden that we believed existed here 500 years ago when the Moors ran the show.
